awd_titl_txt: Compact Binaries and the Origin of Millisecond Pulsars
awd_abstract_narration:
The fastest-spinning neutron stars observable by astronomers have rotation periods of milliseconds and are known as millisecond pulsars.  These stars, of which about 250 are known in the Milky Way Galaxy, are important laboratories for modern astrophysics in fields ranging from general relativity to the study of supernovae.  Most have acquired their brisk spins by accretion of matter from a binary companion, a process known as "pulsar recycling."  However, most of these systems have permanently stopped accreting and have low-mass white dwarf stellar companions, making it impossible to study the pulsar recycling process.   A research team at Michigan State University has developed a method to use the NSF-supported SOAR telescope to discover new pulsars that are still actively accreting, which will allow them to uncover how millisecond pulsars are formed and find new insights into the nature of neutron stars.   The team will do this by observing variable stars near gamma-ray sources newly discovered by NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope, and measuring their detailed physical properties.  The team will mentor undergraduate students in astronomy research, with an emphasis on recruiting members of groups underrepresented in science, and also link public observing at the campus observatory to university football games.

When spun up as millisecond pulsars in binary systems, neutron stars offer stringent tests of general relativity, and the most massive neutron stars can give clues to the details of supernovae explosions and constrain the equation of state of cold nuclear matter at densities exceeding those of atomic nuclei.  The planned work will lead to the discovery of unique neutron star binaries, clarify the existence of new classes of neutron star binaries, inform models for millisecond pulsar evolution, and trace the mass distribution of neutron stars.   These binaries will be further characterized with multi-wavelength radio, X-ray, and gamma-ray data.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Neutron stars are the most extreme stars in the universe, with densities exceeding those of atomic nuclei. Most neutron stars are formed in supernovae: the explosive deaths of massive stars. Neutron stars are born with strong magnetic fields and rapid spins, detectable as radio pulsars visible as cosmic lighthouses. Left alone, neutron stars spin down to slow rotation periods and become hard or impossible to detect.

However, if the neutron star is in a close binary system, its companion star can slowly dump material onto the neutron star as it evolves. As the neutron star accretes this material, it spins back up and can re-emerge as a "recycled" pulsar with a weak magnetic field but a much faster spin period, spinning hundreds of times per second.

The vast majority of millisecond pulsars that formed this way are no longer accreting material from a companion star: all that remains is a binary with the neutron star and a white dwarf---the dead core of the companion. The binary can remain in this configuration for billions of years, slowly spinning down.

One long-standing puzzle is that if you compare the binary star systems that astronomers think will evolve into millisecond pulsars, the stars tend to be much closer to each other than in the millisecond pulsar binaries we know about.

An exciting advance in this field was the ability to discover millisecond pulsars in an entirely new way: using high-energy gamma-rays rather than radio waves. It turns out that many millisecond pulsars had been hidden from easy discovery with radio telescopes, but which have been revealed in the gamma-rays. And the biggest class of millisecond pulsar binaries missing was the long-sought population of very close binaries, where the neutron star
and its companion star complete a full orbit of each other in less than a day.

In these binaries, the energetic neutron star is blowing away the outer layers of its companion, causing it to lose mass, as well as hiding it from the view of radio telescopes, while high-energy gamma-rays can easily penetrate this wind. Hence these systems have been named "spiders", referring to arachnid species where the female sometimes eat the male after mating, just as the recycled neutron star is eating the companion star that originally "fed it".

This project successfully identified many new millisecond pulsar binaries that belong to the spider class, and showed that the neutron stars in these binaries are much heavier than they likely were at birth. These systems may be helpful in figuring out the upper limit to the mass of a neutron star before it collapses into a black hole, and whether there is an upper limit for the spin speed of a pulsar as well.

 

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the proposal focused on providing authentic research opportunities to undergraduates early in their careers, especially students from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. We also held a novel public outreach event associated with football tailgating at Michigan State.
